did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Records of George Charles Poppensiek as Professor of Comparative Medicine at the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, especially relating to collaboration with institutes in other countries, and office records.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: George Charles Poppensiek (1918- ) received his V.M.D. (Latin spelling of D.V.M.) degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1942 and an M.S. from Cornell University in 1951. He taught at the University of Pennsylvania and the University of Maryland before working as a department head with the Lederle Laboratories Division of American Cyanamid Company where he was responsible for veterinary vaccine and antiserum production. In 1949 he came to Cornell to begin graduate studies in virology and pathology. From 1951 to 1955 he served as a research associate in the Veterinary Virus Research Institute at Cornell. From 1955 to 1958, he worked at the U.S.D. A.'s Plum Island Animal Disease Laboratory, working on highly infectious foreign animal diseases. In 1959 he returned to Cornell to become Dean of the New York State Veterinary College at Cornell University, a position he held until 1974. He was then named as the James Law Professor of Comparative Medicine. He retired in 1988. From 1974 to 1988 he also was appointed to the staff of the Department of Preventative Medicine at the Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse as a Research Professor. He belonged to numerous veterinary organizations and served as a consultant to other universities and projects.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Records of George Charles Poppensiek as Professor of Comparative Medicine at the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, especially relating to collaboration with institutes in other countries, and office records, except financial records, for the department.

Also personal files of Dean Poppensiek, including six scrapbooks with clippings, photographs, letters, and certificates, compiled by his wife Edith Marion Wallace Poppensiek, 1943-2006; files with articles, photographs, certificates, and miscellany, 1943-2000; commencement programs, 1942, 1952; writings by George Poppensiek on veterinary and popular topics; consultant's reports; annual reports and other historical publications relating to the College of Veterinary Medicine; and plaques and certificates honoring him. Also many self published writings on various science related subjects that he wrote for his family members to help teach them about the world and engage them in science.

controlaccess.head: Names:
controlaccess.corpname: New York State College of Veterinary Medicine.Dean.
New York State College of Veterinary Medicine.Office of Comparative Medicine.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Any sensitive employee records or administrative files from time as Dean or with the Office of Comparative Medicine, including, but not limited to Box 13 Folders 1 & 2. Restricted to permission of office of origin.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: George Charles Poppensiek papers, #24-2-2149. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

scopecontent.p: Includes: "Hungry Minds and the Empty Bowl of Grammar and Rhetoric", "Emphasis on Concepts in the Teaching of Veterinary Microbiology", "Language in Education: The Neglected Responsibility of Contemporary American Society", "Welcome to Buffalo", "Animal Diseases Transmissible to Man", Veranus Alba Moore obituary from Journal of Bacteriology, July 1931.

Includes: Biography, Marriage advice project interview form, requirements for the George C. Poppensiek visting professorship, press release for winning the Centennial Medal. Also a photo at his desk at the Cornell Vet School and a photo of the 1940 National Alpha Psi fraternity Convention March 22-23, 1940, in Auburn, Alabama

Series V. Material for friends and family, authored/collected by Poppensiek

scopecontent.p: These spiral bound writings were an ongoing effort by Dr. Poppensiek to continue to educate and inform youth and adults alike. The topics are mainly science related and were inspired by his own ideas of knowledge that he thought was important or by subjects and concepts that were relevant to what people close to him were currently learning about in school. While each item is themed they often cover a wide range of topics within a single volume. They contain many color graphics and photos and some contain cover letters placed inside.
